dataset.title: Tea Fire Perimeter (Santa Barbara County, CA), November 15, 2008 - From Geospatial Multi-Agency Coordination Group (GeoMAC)

creator.organizationName: GeoMAC, the Geospatial Multi-Agency Cooridination Group

associatedParty.organizationName: National Weather Service and Bureau of Land Management at NIFC
Remote Sensing Application Center (RSAC, USFS, NASA)

abstract.para: The Tea Fire burned from 2008-11-13 to 2008-11-17, Montecito, Cold Springs Creek and Hot Springs Road, Santa Barbara County. Approximately 1940 acres were burned (information per http://cdfdata.fire.ca.gov). This dataset contains a KML polygon showing the extent of the fire on 2008-11-15, and was acquired by request from the Geospatial Multi-Agency Coordination Group (GeoMAC, http://www.geomac.gov).
These data are based upon input from incident intelligence sources, Global Positioning System (GPS) data, and infrared (IR) imagery. See methods for more information.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Wildland fire perimeters for Tea, 2008. Bounding box shows only maximums and minimums of latititudes and longitudes. See kml file for complete perimeter of fire.

description.para: These data were retrieved from the USGS archive.

contact.positionName: Information Manager, Santa Barbara Coastal LTER

section.para: Data requested from Geospatial Multi-Agency Coordination (GeoMAC).

The Geospatial Multi-Agency Coordination (GeoMAC) has been collecting and storing data on wildland fire perimeters since August 2000. The dataset presented via this U.S. Geological Survey Data Series product contains the GeoMAC wildland fire perimeter data based upon input from incident intelligence sources, Global Positioning System (GPS) data, and infrared (IR) imagery. Wildland fire perimeter data are obtained from the incidents, evaluated for completeness and accuracy, and processed to reflect consistent field names and attributes. After a quality check, the perimeters are loaded to GeoMAC databases, which support the GeoMAC Web application for access by wildland fire managers and the public. The wildland fire perimeters are viewed through the Web application. The data are subsequently archived according to year and state and are made available for downloading through the Internet in shapefile and Keyhole Markup Language (KML) format. These wildland fire perimeter data are also retained for historical, planning, and research purposes. The datasets that pertain to this report can be found on the Rocky Mountain Geographic Science Center HTTP site at http://rmgsc.cr.usgs.gov/outgoing/GeoMAC/historic_fire_data/.

project.title: GeoMac (Geospatial Multi-Agency Coordination) 2008 Wildland Fire Perimeters
